item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
What is this place, anyway?

I want a place to hone skills I don't get to use every day at my regular gig, as well as record the things I learn during the process of failing and learning and, eventually, succeeding with these new skills. I believe that explaining and discussing the things I learn and discover helps me to better understand those things.

This website is also not going to only be about work-related things. I'm passionate about several subjects that I intend to discuss here as well, from fine whisk(e)ys, to my crippling addiction to cars, to music, to…well, whatever I feel like. It is my website, after all.

This website, as well as the links to a few of my social media accounts at the bottom of the page,  will probably contain some naughty words. I might even say something mean.

Just so you know.

So what do I do?

I'm a security-minded web developer. I work for a fairly well-known-in-my-region company in a heavily regulated industry that I'm going to do everything in my power to leave nameless on this website.

Though the things discussed here certainly benefit them, this website isn't about them, and it isn't for them.

How did I make this?

galyonj.com is hosted by Amazon Web Services on Linux. AWS is a fantastic set of tools, though Amazon's home-rolled version of CentOS, Amazon Linux, leaves a couple things to be desired. Frankly, considering the price and the amount of control I have over the server itself and the technologies (and versions of those technologies) I'm able to use…I'm pretty pleased.

The page you are viewing is served to you courtesy of Apache, WordPress, PHP, and MariaDB. The appearance and overall style of the site is a theme I built for myself using Bootstrap, JavaScript, and CSS3. The body copy is Fira Sans, the code examples are Fira Mono, and the headlines and non-body links are a lovely slab serif named Bitter.

I also need to give a big shoutout to zero calorie energy drinks, and extreme metal bands of all sorts, without both of which I'd probably just be sleeping instead of awake and useful. Y'all are the real MVPs.

If this website displays poorly in your browser, you should stop using a shitty browser.

Will I do work for you?

Maybe.
item.excerpt:encoded: This page contains information about the author and site owner, John Galyon, as well as some information about why the website exists at all, and a brief explanation of the technologies and techniques used in the creation thereof.

item.title: Faster web pages for fun and profit
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
Fast web pages make happy users, and happy users mean return visits1. Return visits mean you get to justify your existence. And that means you get to keep raking in those fat website paychecks in your mansion2. There are several techniques and technologies you can use to make your life, as well as the lives of your users, much easier.

So what makes a website fast?

In short, everything from the server you use to the way you format your HTML. First, though, you need to recognize that you only have control over certain things. If your host sucks, there's not much you can do. If you do everything right and your host is awesome, but your users are in Upper Trashcanistan on a choppy 3G connection, they're still gonna have a hard time loading your site. You need to know your users and understand what technological limitations exist at their end of the pipe, and, further, recognize that it doesn't matter how nice the site looks if it doesn't fucking work3.

But let's look at a couple things that you do have control over, and how to make them work for you.

Server-Side

I have better things to do than get into nginx vs apache arguments. Use whatever architecture you're comfortable with. Just know, if you're using Apache 2.2, know that Apache 2.4 is orders of magnitude faster and more efficient. Likewise, if you're still using PHP5.x, you should know that PHP5.6 officially reached end of support on 31 December 2016, and will only receive security patches until it's official end of life at the beginning of 2019. You should also know that PHP7 blows PHP5.6 out of the water in terms of speed and processor load.

Just keeping current can make you faster.

If you're using WordPress, there are about a billion reasons you should make sure you're current on that installation, but WordPress 4.7 also has some slight efficiency and performance gains over earlier versions.

A quick aside – if you can set up HTTP/2 (it's a little early, and probably a lot of hosts won't do it), you stand to gain a significant performance improvement by doing so.

WordPress

You could use plugins to do all this, pretty much; but what's the fun in that?

Instead, let's talk about some simple rules you can add to your .htaccess file.

[snippet slug=htaccess-deflate-rules lang=html]

The above does two things. First, it invokes the mod_deflate plugin for Apache, then we provide a list of all the different file types we want compressed. Mod_deflate is a compression utility that's built into Apache, and it can make files very small indeed. Small files make for faster loading. The second statement invokes mod_expires, which we can use to set expiration dates to tell the browser how long to keep files of a given MIME type around, so things are even faster for repeat visitors to the site. You set the expiration using pretty much the same logic you'd use to set cookie expiration.

If you have access to it, you don't even need a .htaccess file. You can add these rules directly to your Apache httpd.conf file, and you'll get an additional slight performance bump by simplifying the file system.

Stupid functions.php tricks

Lastly, there are a  couple things you can add to your theme's function.php file to accomplish a few different objectives.

  1. Strip the WordPress version number from theme files shown on the front-end (this is a good security practice – the thinking being that if one doesn't know what version of WordPress you're using, it's harder to decide how to attack you).
  2. Add the UNIX timestamp of the last time the file was modified as an argument to theme files to force the browser to load the new version of that file if it's been updated since the last visit.

Remove the WordPress version number

[snippet slug=filters-remove-version-numbers-theme-scripts-stylesheets lang=php]

remove_morrigan_ver_css_js is given one argument, $src. $src a variable used by WordPress to, in this case, store the source URL of enqueued stylesheets and scripts. The if statement that runs when the function is called searches the output of the $src variable for a string that begins with "ver=" and ends with the currently installed version of WordPress. If it finds that string, it strips it out and returns the newly cleaned string for WordPress to use.

Two filters then call the function, and each filter acccepts three arguments (because that's all we need for this purpose): the hook we're passing to the filter, the name of the function we want to pass to the hook, and the priority of the filter.

Priority is defined as follows:

$priority

(int) (Optional) Used to specify the order in which the functions associated with a particular action are executed. Lower numbers correspond with earlier execution, and functions with the same priority are executed in the order in which they were added to the action.

Enqueue scripts and styles and add last-modified timestamp

This is where the cachebusting magic comes in. We've got to make sure WordPress enqueues the theme-specific stylesheets and script files, but with all the caching we discussed earlier, this presents an issue when we need to update those items. This is how we can force the browser to load the updated version of these files without hammering the refresh key.

[snippet slug=enqueue-scripts-styles-twist lang=php]

So gj_enqueue is a pretty sweet little function. At the beginning, we create two variables,  $js_path and $css_path, and each of those store the location in the server's file system where those files reside. We'll need those later.

Next up is morrigan_enqueue_script and morrigan_enqueue_style, which are pretty standard, You can learn about them here and here, respectively. The only special thing we're doing is, instead of adding a hard-coded value to the version number argument, $ver, we're calling filemtime, which is a very simple function built into PHP that returns, as an integer, the UNIX timestamp of the last time a given file was written or modified. We then feed the variables we made at the top of the function to filemtime, and we have our new $ver value.

So this version number changes every single time you update one of the files in this function, thus forcing the browser to respect the updated file. This is what the output looks like on this site:

[snippet slug=versioned-files-output lang=html]
item.excerpt:encoded: This is where the cachebusting magic comes in. We've got to make sure WordPress enqueues the theme-specific stylesheets and script files, but with all the caching we discussed earlier, this presents an issue when we need to update those items.

item.title: Bootstrap Breadcrumbs in WordPress
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
So I'm obviously a big fan of Bootstrap. I'm also obviously a big fan of WordPress. You know what I'm not a big fan of? Using an assload of plugins. I have better things to do with my time than constantly tend to a pack of nagging, buggy plugins. Not only does something always need to be updated; but, more and more, I find myself dissatisfied with the output they produce, especially when one weighs that against the overhead (in time, page load speed, and system resources) that they cost to use. If we're already loading massive libraries like Bootstrap and jQuery, we may as well leverage the tools provided.

What are we doing?

Making sure that your user has an easy time navigating your website is just the polite thing to do. To that end, breadcrumbs can be a useful tool – a quick reference for the user to show them, visually, how to get back to where they came from, as well as offering the opportunity to make potentially interesting stops along the way. If you want to also not have to completely reinvent the wheel, you can use the tools already provided by your framework of choice. Obviously, this walkthrough focuses on Bootstrap 3.3.7, but because it uses as little extra markup as possible, it should be fairly easy to adapt to Bootstrap 4 or Foundation, or even something you've rolled on your own (and more power to you for that). There are a few moving parts here that I want to go over, and they'll each get their turn.

PHP

This is the star of the show. This'll live in your theme's functions.php file. What's going on here is fairly self-explanatory. We first need to declare a function bs_breadcrumbs. What this function will do is create a list that – provided the current page isn't the home page – displays the current page title as well as links to each ancestor of the current page. In keeping with the structure of Bootstrap v.3.3.7's breadcrumbs, the first item output is an ordered list of class breadcrumb. Then we dump a list item containing a link to the home page of the site. Then…things get a little crazy. Given how many different things for which we need to account, with every imaginable post type, author pages, archives, and so on, this becomes a fairly big function for such a simple thing. If you want to cull out things that aren't useful to you, knock yourself out. But I think this does a pretty good job of both staying out of the way as well as covering a lot of possible display scenarios. I've not found anything that breaks it yet, and I've used it with custom post types as well as plugin-generated content. https://gist.github.com/galyonj/26d04f325f8d4bf7d469c003afc9bb28

MOAR PHP

Now that we have our function written, we have to give it a place to live on the template pages. There are probably as many different, wholly appropriate ways to place the function call as there are WordPress installations; but generally speaking, you want it somewhere near the top of the page if you expect it to be useful to your users, so it makes sense to place it either in a header.php file, or towards the top of your page, post, category, etc templates (like I'm doing for this site, since I made a flipperbaby that has all the navigation in a column). https://gist.github.com/galyonj/6f36719610e8acb1efcd5b02d05f8128 That's it. Place the one line in your template files, and it checks to make sure the function exists, then calls it. The function itself does all the hard work.

Style It

I'm one of the laziest human beings on earth (which I why I write code for a living instead of doing something useful like digging ditches). While we're already making the user download Bootstrap's CSS and JS files, as well as jQuery and whatever else all the plugins we're using is forcing down our throats, we may as well use that to our advantage. We're gonna let Bootstrap do the heavy lifting for us instead of adding more markup to the page (and to our functions.php file). The example below is from my _type.scss file for this site, and all it does is overwrite Bootstrap's existing breadcrumb styles. You can cut down on download weight even more by just editing the core Bootstrap files, but that makes updating your Bootstrap version down the road much more of a chore. All I've done here is change a few of the settings to better suit my personal use case. Go nuts here. The world's yer oyster. https://gist.github.com/galyonj/aaa460ec950fcbe44163c623407623c2 And here's a fairly simple example of what the output looks like on the page. https://gist.github.com/galyonj/8f8d331252da168a8ddaa552b0d57889 Easy, right?
item.excerpt:encoded: In which we use the built-in functionality provided by Bootstrap and Wordpress to our advantage to make accessible, useful breadcrumbs.

item.title: On firing a client
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
There are a lot of reasons that I don't entertain many offers for freelance work. Chief among them are the fact that, often, I have to constantly justify my own existence to the client – as if I'm somehow putting one over on them. After all, all I do is sit and play with computers all day, right? Over the years, I've found that it's not an efficient use of my time to convince every trinket peddler that I'm worth what I charge. Quite frankly, I have better things to do than convince the transmission shop down the street why their website needs secure practices just as much as does that of a hospital or a bank, just like I'm not going to sit on hold with your $5/month shit-tier hosting plan to figure out why they stuck 200 tenants on a machine that couldn't handle half that many on its best day. I'm a whore and can be bought just like anybody else. However, I've quite intentionally set my price to be high enough to scare off certain types of would-be clients.

Know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em

Occasionally, though, I have to reacquaint myself with all the reasons why I operate like this. Recently I took on a new client. This client had a long-standing relationship with a colleague of mine that did his print design, and he was having some problems with his website. Sure, I'll talk to him. Maybe it's a quick fix, and, having seen the kind of work my friend's been doing with him, I figured this client might be interested in a more comprehensive project down the road. So we emailed for a bit, then we met and planned some stuff out, and before you know it, we were talking about a complete rebrand of his business. He was going to be introducing more products to his market, needed security, an online storefront that actually works, all that good stuff. And…then I began to feel the pangs of buck fever.

Know when to walk away

When I do a project, dear reader, I do a damn project. I put together a brief identifying everything we needed to do to get him up to standards, make a website that would be easy for him to curate with minimal involvement on my part after go-live, create an extensible home for his existing brand on the web that could then easily be transitioned to his new brand whenever that came about. Holy shit was it good. Then, one Thursday morning, I got a phone call. "John," sayeth the client, "I need a website for a trade show. Can you do that for me? It doesn't have to be much, I just have to show some products and stuff." "Well, I guess I could do that. When do you need it up?" "Monday, but I'd like to see it before my flight on Sunday." "Um…it'll take me just about all weekend, but sure. This isn't part of the contract that we've signed for the other work, you understand? I can probably reuse some of the code, but it's gonna be very much thrown together." "Alright, well, I really need it." And, thus, the bell was rung. I truncated my whole process, spun up an EC2 Micro instance on AWS, secured it, bought a domain (cause we couldn't use his existing domain), and coded a pretty basic website over the course of a weekend. Finished up at around midnight on that Sunday, sent my invoice off on Monday.

…and know when to run

A couple days later, I received an email.
John, Your bill for $$$$$ is unacceptable. See attached Godaddy site can be built in less than an hour. or you could have saved the website site under another name and added 4 images. This does need to get resolved, Regards, Client
So…couple things here.
  • Sure, I could've paid for hosting and gotten stuck with that bill just like I did the domain name I registered, but GoDaddy's on my list of web hosts with which I'll never do business.
  • I could've easily shat something out in a couple hours, but I chose to create something that could then be used to bootstrap the development of the long-term site and, in the end, give the client a better, more useful toolset.
  • If it's so easy, what do you need me for?
Further, the whole experience (and a couple other things that happened along the way) kind of gave me a glimpse into a possible future for myself, and I didn't much like what I saw. I already have a job that I enjoy very, very much, and into which I put a lot of myself. I did not wish to be this person's personal IT department, and, further, the implications set forth in his email regarding the value of the work I do kind of hacked me off. Here is what the (now former, I guess) client received in reply.
Client, I had several goals in carrying out the tasks we discussed on $date:
  • Being that I already put myself on the hook for a domain name for the rush project, I did not wish to enter into a business agreement that I cannot easily extricate myself from with a hosting company that we may well not using going forward for a one-off project – hence the use of Amazon’s hosting, which required the server be set up.
  • The templates for pages and the online store were created in such a way that they could easily be repurposed for the final, long-term version of your website – hence the amount of effort that was put into creating them.
  • Colors aside, the basic design of the rush demo site, again, was intended to be easily repurposed for use on the final version of the website.
I take issue with your implication that the work I do is of no more value than GoDaddy’s website builder product. I have to admit that I’m a little confused, also. If what you needed was so easy that it could be built, by your own reckoning, in under an hour, I cannot understand why you didn’t just do that – especially given the rush you were in to see the work completed. Finally, I believe this can easily be resolved with the following: I regret that you are so clearly unhappy with the work that I’ve provided thus far, further, I fear that this experience may color our dealings going forward. For that reason, I recommend that we simply end the business relationship. Don’t concern yourself with the invoice, and don’t concern yourself with the existing contract for the other work. You owe me nothing, and I wish you well.
All of this could've been avoided, and I offer myself, today, as a cautionary tale for the reader: Always. Have. A. Contract. Everything you do on another party's behalf needs to be clearly spelled out and agreed upon – in writing – before you lift a finger. I wasted more time than I'm willing to admit relearning this lesson, but I feel, also, like I potentially dodged a bullet. Also, I know you have that song stuck in your head now.
item.excerpt:encoded: I wasted more time than I'm willing to admit relearning this lesson. I feel, also, like I dodged a bullet here.

item.title: 2016 Mustang GT stereo upgrade
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
I think the 6th generation Mustang GT is a fantastic car. Well-mannered when you're just driving around normally in traffic, while at the same time capable of being a complete animal once you decide to open the taps. The cabin is well-appointed and comfortable, the body lines are sexy – as far as I'm concerned, this is the best looking Mustang since the platform received its first major restyle in 1969, and the new Coyote 302ci engine (even unmodified from the factory) is pretty great. I have pretty low standards because most of the things I've driven have been some combination of old and shitty, but this car's legit.

There are a couple flies in the ointment, though. This article is aimed at swatting one of them.

The subject of this article is a 2016 Mustang GT Premium with the 400A equipment package, which means, among other things, this Mustang came with the 9 speaker stereo system paired with the excellent Sync 3 control system for the car's bluetooth/nav/whatever functionality.

That reads well on paper, but it actually sounds like shit. The factory stereo can get plenty loud, but the output is thin and reedy. It's fine, I guess, for people that don't actually like music.

So we're going to fix that.

[well]

Preface

If you don't know how to solder, stop reading this.

If you don't know how to do basic maintenance on a vehicle, stop reading this.

Nothing you're about to read is cool enough for you to start hacking at your chassis wiring unless you know what you're doing.

Go pay somebody to do it for you.

If you decide to do this anyway, know that all I'll do if you contact me and tell me that you've fucked your car up in the process of following this article is point and laugh. If you're grown enough to buy a nice car and get to this website on your own, then you're grown enough to own your mistakes. I will not be held responsible for you not having your shit together.

Don't give me that look.

[/well]

Project outline

The point of this exercise is to enhance the existing stereo, not to overpower it. To that end, and taking into account the limited amount of space in the trunk, we'll be installing a Kicker 10" Comp C subwoofer enclosed in a small ported box. The subwoofer will handle 300W RMS at 4Ω,  and it's being paired with a Kicker 43DXA250.1 mono amp rated for 125W RMS at 4Ω. To get signal for the amp, we'll be tapping into the existing wiring harness right above where the speaker box sits to wire in a Scosche line out converter.

[caption id="attachment_155" align="alignnone" width="1200"] The finished product of this installation, a Kicker Comp 10" subwoofer in a thin-mount box, tucked away behind the rear seats of this Mustang. Some cleanup needs to be done to the wiring, but this'll keep until it's not cold and shitty outside.[/caption]

The process

This, as with everything to do with modifying or working on automobiles, is easy to do if you take your time and think before you do anything stupid. Measure 17 times so that you can cut once in the perfect spot.

Step 1 – safety first

Disconnect the negative battery cable. This ought to be step one for every single thing you do to the electrical system of a car – especially one like this that has eleventy billion fuses and sensors. Electricity hurts.

To disconnect the negative battery cable, you'll need to remove the battery cover on the car. It's up against the firewall on the passenger side, and there are three little plastic screws holding it down. Remove those and pull up and towards the front of the car to remove the cover. You can now remove the negative battery cable from the terminal with a 10mm deep-well socket, and lay it outside the battery box. You do not want this cable touching anything until you're finished with the project.

Chock the rear tires, engage the parking brake, and jack up the car. The bulkhead entrance into the cabin is behind the passenger side fender liner, so we've got to take some stuff off that corner in order to get room to work. Jack the car up using the pinch weld just aft of the front passenger wheel, then put a jack stand under the front subframe just inboard of the lower control arm. Lower the car onto the stand, then remove the front passenger side wheel and set it out of the way, cause you won't be needing that for a while.

Step 2 – running the power cable

For this installation, I used a 4AWG Fleks cable from KnuKonceptz. Never used them before, but I'm pretty impressed. It didn't put up much fight when I made a couple tight bends to get everything tucked away like I wanted.

[caption id="attachment_160" align="alignnone" width="1200"] The 4AWG cable that supplies 12v power to the amplifier is tucked between the battery box and the strut tower. Once the project is complete, the battery cover conceals all of this.[/caption]

Next, we have to remove the front passenger side fender liner. Once you have the fender liner off the car (be careful not to break any of the trim locks that keep it in place, because you'll need those later), you can run the 12v power wire.

Terminate the cable, measure out about 12" and cut it, then splice in your inline fuse holder. You can now connect the terminated end to the positive terminal on the battery, and can feed the unterminated end of the cable into the space between the engine bay and the fender.

Once you've fed the cable through the fender, you'll note that there's a nipple on the grommet through which the PCM wiring (that's the great big wire loom that you see snaking from the engine bay into the fender well) is fed into the cabin of the vehicle. Cut that nipple off and feed your new 12v cable through the opening. You'll have to put a little muscle behind it to get it through the carpet padding, but it'll go.

Once you have it started, go into the passenger-side footwell and feel around up under the glove box, peel the carpet back a little bit, and you should be able to feel the end of the cable. Once you have ahold of it, pull it on through, making sure to leave some slack in the engine bay and fender well so that you don't put unnecessary strain on the cable.

When you've got it pulled through, you can put the fender liner back in, put the wheel back on, and take the car off the jack stand. At this point, we're done with the outside of the vehicle.

[caption id="attachment_163" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Pictured here, the passenger side of the Mustang's cabin with the trim removed. This allows us to cleanly tuck the wiring that leads from the front of the car to the amplifier in the trunk. That fat blue cable is the 12v power from the battery, and the thinner black wire is the signal-strength dial for the line out converter.[/caption]

The line out converter I used has a separate cable that allows the occupant to dial in how much subwoofer they want to hear in the mix. I mounted it in the glove box so that it stays out of the way and keeps the interior clean while also remaining accessible. To run the cable for this, I dropped the end out of the back of the glove box, and it'll follow the power cable to the trunk.

Step 3 – tuck that ish

Nobody wants to get in your car with a fire hazard snaking across the carpet. Comb your hair, you look like a daggum hippie. Call your mama once in a while. Have some pride in yourself, dang.

To properly tuck the wires, the following items need to be removed from the vehicle:

  • the passenger side kick panels (there are two, a big one and a little one, and they both come out at once),
  • the passenger side door sill,
  • the back seat bottom.

To remove the trim panels, just pull, gently, with your fingertips, at spots along the length of each panel. They're just held in by clips.

To remove the seat bottom, poke your fingertips up under the seat and feel around for a tab. If you press the tab back towards the rear of the cabin, you'll be able to lift the seat bottom out and forwards out of the car.

We also need to pull the B pillar trim loose so that we can snake the cable through it and then feed it up over the seat pan and under the seat back into the trunk. There's no need to try to completely remove this trim panel.

Now that you have room to work, get your RuPaul on and start tucking.

Using electrical tape, bundle the power cable and signal cable together as close to the point the power cable enters the cabin as you can get, then gently pull the carpet and sound deadening material back, and tuck the cables under there – you don't have to go crazy, remember that all this is going to be hidden by the trim anyway. About every foot, do another wrap of tape just to make sure the cables stay bundled nicely.

Once you've got them fed back into the trunk, put all the trim and the back seat bottom back where you found it, in exactly this order:

  • The large passenger side kick panel piece snaps into the A pillar trim and down along the door sill
  • The small passenger side kick panel piece snaps down into the firewall-side of the large piece
  • The B pillar trim snaps back into place
  • The door sill trim snaps over the rest
  • The rear seat back goes back in (make sure to pull the seatbelt latches through the holes in the upholstery)
[caption id="attachment_166" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Isn't that nice? The cables are all snug and tucked in. This Mustang looks like we were never there. If a cripple can do it in a freezing-ass garage, so can you.[/caption]

Step 4 – the easy part’s over

I wouldn't call this the “hard part” so much as it's kind of a pain in the ass.

Go ahead and plug your soldering iron in and put it somewhere that it won't melt anything, cause you're gonna need it in a few minutes.

We gotta clean off a spot to terminate the ground cable for the amplifier. Luckily, the Mustang engineering team was looking out for us. Lay both halves of the back seat down, and you'll see a little fabric tongue poking out into the trunk area. Under this tongue is a 15mm bolt. Remove the bolt, and grab a file, and scrape all the paint off the body metal under that tongue. When you're done, put the bolt back, and use it to squash the stripped end of your ground cable. The other end of that cable, of course, will go to the ground terminal on the amplifier.

Collect the following, cause you're gonna need all of it here in a minute:

  • Solder
  • Soldering iron (just have a lovely assistant hand it to you when you need it, cause burnt carpet smells awful)
  • Three 2-3" pieces of wire to use as extensions
  • Wire cutters/strippers
  • A sharp knife
  • A work light
  • Something soft to rest your head on – you're gonna be laying in the trunk for a little bit

Lay in the trunk with your head towards the back seat, like I'm doing in the picture at the top of the page.

Right in front of your eyes, you'll see the passenger-side rear speaker, and a wiring loom. Very carefully, cut that loom apart to expose the wires inside it. It'll look something like this when you're done.

[caption id="attachment_168" align="alignnone" width="1200"] The exposed rear-deck wiring for the 2015-2017 Mustang. In this picture, the first connection has already been made and (sloppily) taped up.[/caption]

There are exactly three wires with which you need concern yourself:

  • Brown with a white stripe: passenger rear speaker positive
  • Brown with a blue stripe: passenger rear speaker negative
  • Yellow with a green stripe: 12v switched power (this powers the antenna turn-on signal)

The brown wires will be twisted together, and the yellow wire will be buried at the back of the bundle.

You need to tap into these to match positive->positive, negative->negative, and 12v->remote, joining the factory chassis wiring to the line out converter. Refer to the wiring diagram for your line out converter to be sure that you're not joining the wrong wires.

Once you're done, wrap the whole thing up and zip-tie the converter to that harness so that it's tucked up out of the way. Just a few things left to do:

  • Run your RCA cable and your remote wire from the line out converter to the amplifier
  • Plug the subwoofer controller cable into the line out converter
  • Terminate the ground and power cables at the amplifier
  • Reconnect the negative battery cable and button the battery cover back up
  • Clean up your mess. You'll have bits of copper everywhere.
item.excerpt:encoded: Despite the name, the stereo in the S550 Mustang ain't shaking shit. In this article, we fix that.

item.title: 2016 Mustang GT Stereo Upgrade
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
I think the 6th generation Mustang GT is a fantastic car. Well-mannered when you're just driving around normally in traffic, while at the same time capable of being a complete animal once you decide to open the taps. The cabin is well-appointed and comfortable, the body lines are sexy – as far as I'm concerned, this is the best looking Mustang since the platform received its first major restyle in 1969, and the new Coyote 302ci engine (even unmodified from the factory) is pretty great. I have pretty low standards because most of the things I've driven have been some combination of old and shitty, but this car's legit. There are a couple flies in the ointment, though. This article is aimed at swatting one of them. The subject of this article is a 2016 Mustang GT Premium with the 400A equipment package, which means, among other things, this Mustang came with the 9 speaker stereo system paired with the excellent Sync 3 control system for the car's bluetooth/nav/whatever functionality. That reads well on paper, but it actually sounds like shit. The factory stereo can get plenty loud, but the output is thin and reedy. It's fine, I guess, for people that don't actually like music. So we're going to fix that. [well]

Preface

If you don't know how to solder, stop reading this. If you don't know how to do basic maintenance on a vehicle, stop reading this. Nothing you're about to read is cool enough for you to start hacking at your chassis wiring unless you know what you're doing. Go pay somebody to do it for you. If you decide to do this anyway, know that all I'll do if you contact me and tell me that you've fucked your car up in the process of following this article is point and laugh. If you're grown enough to buy a nice car and get to this website on your own, then you're grown enough to own your mistakes. I will not be held responsible for you not having your shit together. Don't give me that look. [/well]

Project outline

The point of this exercise is to enhance the existing stereo, not to overpower it. To that end, and taking into account the limited amount of space in the trunk, we'll be installing a Kicker 10" Comp C subwoofer enclosed in a small ported box. The subwoofer will handle 300W RMS at 4Ω,  and it's being paired with a Kicker 43DXA250.1 mono amp rated for 125W RMS at 4Ω. To get signal for the amp, we'll be tapping into the existing wiring harness right above where the speaker box sits to wire in a Scosche line out converter. [caption id="attachment_155" align="alignnone" width="1200"] The finished product of this installation, a Kicker Comp 10" subwoofer in a thin-mount box, tucked away behind the rear seats of this Mustang. Some cleanup needs to be done to the wiring, but this'll keep until it's not cold and shitty outside.[/caption]

The process

This, as with everything to do with modifying or working on automobiles, is easy to do if you take your time and think before you do anything stupid. Measure 17 times so that you can cut once in the perfect spot.

Step 1 – safety first

Disconnect the negative battery cable. This ought to be step one for every single thing you do to the electrical system of a car – especially one like this that has eleventy billion fuses and sensors. Electricity hurts. To disconnect the negative battery cable, you'll need to remove the battery cover on the car. It's up against the firewall on the passenger side, and there are three little plastic screws holding it down. Remove those and pull up and towards the front of the car to remove the cover. You can now remove the negative battery cable from the terminal with a 10mm deep-well socket, and lay it outside the battery box. You do not want this cable touching anything until you're finished with the project. Chock the rear tires, engage the parking brake, and jack up the car. The bulkhead entrance into the cabin is behind the passenger side fender liner, so we've got to take some stuff off that corner in order to get room to work. Jack the car up using the pinch weld just aft of the front passenger wheel, then put a jack stand under the front subframe just inboard of the lower control arm. Lower the car onto the stand, then remove the front passenger side wheel and set it out of the way, cause you won't be needing that for a while.

Step 2 – running the power cable

For this installation, I used a 4AWG Fleks cable from KnuKonceptz. Never used them before, but I'm pretty impressed. It didn't put up much fight when I made a couple tight bends to get everything tucked away like I wanted. [caption id="attachment_160" align="alignnone" width="1200"] The 4AWG cable that supplies 12v power to the amplifier is tucked between the battery box and the strut tower. Once the project is complete, the battery cover conceals all of this.[/caption] Next, we have to remove the front passenger side fender liner. Once you have the fender liner off the car (be careful not to break any of the trim locks that keep it in place, because you'll need those later), you can run the 12v power wire. Terminate the cable, measure out about 12" and cut it, then splice in your inline fuse holder. You can now connect the terminated end to the positive terminal on the battery, and can feed the unterminated end of the cable into the space between the engine bay and the fender. Once you've fed the cable through the fender, you'll note that there's a nipple on the grommet through which the PCM wiring (that's the great big wire loom that you see snaking from the engine bay into the fender well) is fed into the cabin of the vehicle. Cut that nipple off and feed your new 12v cable through the opening. You'll have to put a little muscle behind it to get it through the carpet padding, but it'll go. Once you have it started, go into the passenger-side footwell and feel around up under the glove box, peel the carpet back a little bit, and you should be able to feel the end of the cable. Once you have ahold of it, pull it on through, making sure to leave some slack in the engine bay and fender well so that you don't put unnecessary strain on the cable. When you've got it pulled through, you can put the fender liner back in, put the wheel back on, and take the car off the jack stand. At this point, we're done with the outside of the vehicle. [caption id="attachment_163" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Pictured here, the passenger side of the Mustang's cabin with the trim removed. This allows us to cleanly tuck the wiring that leads from the front of the car to the amplifier in the trunk. That fat blue cable is the 12v power from the battery, and the thinner black wire is the signal-strength dial for the line out converter.[/caption] The line out converter I used has a separate cable that allows the occupant to dial in how much subwoofer they want to hear in the mix. I mounted it in the glove box so that it stays out of the way and keeps the interior clean while also remaining accessible. To run the cable for this, I dropped the end out of the back of the glove box, and it'll follow the power cable to the trunk.

Step 3 – tuck that ish

Nobody wants to get in your car with a fire hazard snaking across the carpet. Comb your hair, you look like a daggum hippie. Call your mama once in a while. Have some pride in yourself, dang. To properly tuck the wires, the following items need to be removed from the vehicle:
  • the passenger side kick panels (there are two, a big one and a little one, and they both come out at once),
  • the passenger side door sill,
  • the back seat bottom.
To remove the trim panels, just pull, gently, with your fingertips, at spots along the length of each panel. They're just held in by clips. To remove the seat bottom, poke your fingertips up under the seat and feel around for a tab. If you press the tab back towards the rear of the cabin, you'll be able to lift the seat bottom out and forwards out of the car. We also need to pull the B pillar trim loose so that we can snake the cable through it and then feed it up over the seat pan and under the seat back into the trunk. There's no need to try to completely remove this trim panel. Now that you have room to work, get your RuPaul on and start tucking. Using electrical tape, bundle the power cable and signal cable together as close to the point the power cable enters the cabin as you can get, then gently pull the carpet and sound deadening material back, and tuck the cables under there – you don't have to go crazy, remember that all this is going to be hidden by the trim anyway. About every foot, do another wrap of tape just to make sure the cables stay bundled nicely. Once you've got them fed back into the trunk, put all the trim and the back seat bottom back where you found it, in exactly this order:
  • The large passenger side kick panel piece snaps into the A pillar trim and down along the door sill
  • The small passenger side kick panel piece snaps down into the firewall-side of the large piece
  • The B pillar trim snaps back into place
  • The door sill trim snaps over the rest
  • The rear seat back goes back in (make sure to pull the seatbelt latches through the holes in the upholstery)
[caption id="attachment_166" align="alignnone" width="1200"] Isn't that nice? The cables are all snug and tucked in. This Mustang looks like we were never there. If a cripple can do it in a freezing-ass garage, so can you.[/caption]

Step 4 – the easy part’s over

I wouldn't call this the “hard part” so much as it's kind of a pain in the ass. Go ahead and plug your soldering iron in and put it somewhere that it won't melt anything, cause you're gonna need it in a few minutes. We gotta clean off a spot to terminate the ground cable for the amplifier. Luckily, the Mustang engineering team was looking out for us. Lay both halves of the back seat down, and you'll see a little fabric tongue poking out into the trunk area. Under this tongue is a 15mm bolt. Remove the bolt, and grab a file, and scrape all the paint off the body metal under that tongue. When you're done, put the bolt back, and use it to squash the stripped end of your ground cable. The other end of that cable, of course, will go to the ground terminal on the amplifier. Collect the following, cause you're gonna need all of it here in a minute:
  • Solder
  • Soldering iron (just have a lovely assistant hand it to you when you need it, cause burnt carpet smells awful)
  • Three 2-3" pieces of wire to use as extensions
  • Wire cutters/strippers
  • A sharp knife
  • A work light
  • Something soft to rest your head on – you're gonna be laying in the trunk for a little bit
Lay in the trunk with your head towards the back seat, like I'm doing in the picture at the top of the page. Right in front of your eyes, you'll see the passenger-side rear speaker, and a wiring loom. Very carefully, cut that loom apart to expose the wires inside it. It'll look something like this when you're done. [caption id="attachment_168" align="alignnone" width="1200"] The exposed rear-deck wiring for the 2015-2017 Mustang. In this picture, the first connection has already been made and (sloppily) taped up.[/caption] There are exactly three wires with which you need concern yourself:
  • Brown with a white stripe: passenger rear speaker positive
  • Brown with a blue stripe: passenger rear speaker negative
  • Yellow with a green stripe: 12v switched power (this powers the antenna turn-on signal)
The brown wires will be twisted together, and the yellow wire will be buried at the back of the bundle. You need to tap into these to match positive->positive, negative->negative, and 12v->remote, joining the factory chassis wiring to the line out converter. Refer to the wiring diagram for your line out converter to be sure that you're not joining the wrong wires. Once you're done, wrap the whole thing up and zip-tie the converter to that harness so that it's tucked up out of the way. Just a few things left to do:
  • Run your RCA cable and your remote wire from the line out converter to the amplifier
  • Plug the subwoofer controller cable into the line out converter
  • Terminate the ground and power cables at the amplifier
  • Reconnect the negative battery cable and button the battery cover back up
  • Clean up your mess. You'll have bits of copper everywhere.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Shaker stereo in the S550 Mustang ain't shaking shit. Let's fix that, shall we?

item.title: In which I write a letter
item.dc:creator: jgalyon
item.content:encoded:
More than likely, writing an email to my congresspeople won't make a damn bit of difference. What the hell, right?

As your constituent and a small business owner, I'm writing to urge you to protect the FCC's 2015 Open Internet Order.

Like many Americans, my options for access to the web are limited to only a few providers. These providers – cable companies and wireless carriers – are actively lobbying the FCC for the power to impose arbitrarily low data caps, establish artificial speed caps, and set up a system by which assets on the web are blocked unless additional access fees are paid.

According to recent news reports by the Wall Street Journal and Reuters, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai plans to reverse the FCC's reclassification of broadband Internet providers as common carriers, and substitute the FCC's net neutrality rules with empty industry promises.

Allowing internet providers such as cable companies and wireless carriers to strengthen their monopoly power over the internet will stifle innovation and cripple small businesses like mine.

Please oppose any attempt by Chairman Pai to roll back the FCC's net neutrality protections.In addition, please oppose any effort in Congress to undermine the Open Internet Order.

A free and open Internet is essential for a free society. I urge you to resist attempts to weaken net neutrality protections and entrench Internet monopolies.
